content:
The Act titled "Drug Trafficking Vessel Interdiction Act of 2008" addresses the criminal prohibition of operating submersible vessels without nationality, highlighting the serious international problem it poses in facilitating transnational crime, including drug trafficking and terrorism. This presents a specific threat to maritime navigation safety and the security of the United States. The Act "Drug Trafficking Vessel Interdiction Act of 2008" amends Chapter 111 of title 18, United States Code, by adding a new section that criminalizes operating submersible vessels without nationality to evade detection. Offenders face fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or both. Indicia of intent to evade detection are specified. The Act criminalizes operating submersible vessels without nationality to evade detection. Indicia of intent to evade detection include possession of documents evidencing nationality, flying the nation's flag, or a verbal claim of nationality. Extraterritorial jurisdiction applies, and there are affirmative defenses available. Affirmative defenses to prosecution for operating submersible vessels without nationality include vessel being lawfully registered, classed by a classification society, and operated in government-regulated areas. The affirmative defenses for operating submersible vessels without nationality include being lawfully registered, equipped with tracking systems, and producing relevant government documents or classification certificates. The section outlines exceptions for lawfully authorized activities by the United States Government and references other provisions for offenses related to submersible vessels. SEC. 103. SENTENCING GUIDELINES for the operation of submersible vessels or semi-submersible vessels without nationality. The United States Sentencing Commission will create sentencing guidelines for individuals convicted of operating submersible vessels in violation of the law, ensuring penalties reflect the seriousness of the offense and deterrence measures are in place. The United States Sentencing Commission will establish sentencing guidelines for individuals convicted of using submersible vessels to commit felonies, considering aggravating or mitigating circumstances such as repeated use, involvement in criminal organizations, and flagrant violations of the law. The United States Sentencing Commission will establish sentencing guidelines for individuals convicted of using submersible vessels to commit felonies, considering aggravating or mitigating circumstances such as destruction of vessels, failure to comply with law enforcement, and sentencing enhancements. The guidelines will ensure consistency with other directives, make necessary changes, and meet the purposes of sentencing. The sentencing guidelines for individuals using submersible vessels to commit felonies will ensure consistency with directives and meet the purposes of sentencing as outlined in section 3553(a)(2) of title 18, United States Code. TITLE II--CIVIL PROHIBITION

SEC. 201. OPERATION OF SUBMERSIBLE VESSEL OR SEMI-SUBMERSIBLE VESSEL WITHOUT NATIONALITY.

    Amends Section 70501 of title 46, United States Code to address the serious international problem of operating submersible vessels without nationality, which facilitates transnational crime and terrorism.

SEC. 202. OPERATION PROHIBITED. The amendment to Chapter 705 of title 46, United States Code prohibits individuals from operating or embarking in submersible vessels without nationality with the intent to evade detection in international waters. Indicia of intent to evade detection can be used as evidence in civil enforcement proceedings. The amendment to Chapter 705 of title 46, United States Code prohibits operating submersible vessels without nationality to evade detection. Defenses include vessel registration, classification society approval, and lawful operation in government-regulated areas. The defenses provided by this subsection are proved conclusively by the production of government documents evidencing the vessel's nationality, a certificate of classification from the vessel's classification society, or proof of lawful operation in government-regulated activities. Civil Penalty: A person violating this section shall be liable to the United States for a civil penalty of not more than $1,000,000. Conforming Amendments: The chapter analysis for chapter 705 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to include this new provision. SEC. 203 defines submersible vessel and semi-submersible vessel. Amendments are made to sections 70504(b) and 70505 of title 46, United States Code. SEC. 203 defines semi-submersible and submersible vessels as watercraft capable of operating partially or completely below the water surface.
